item.title: Razer's New Bladeless Gaming Chair Fan Will Keep You Cool--Or Warm--While You Play
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/razers-new-bladeless-gaming-chair-fan-will-keep-you-cool-or-warm-while-you-play/1100-6528681/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Razer brought a bunch of new gaming hardware and accessories to show off at CES 2025 this week, including two big additions to its gaming chair lineup. The first of these gaming chair announcements is the Project Arielle Fan System, a bladeless fan add-on for Razer's Fujin and Fujin Pro mesh gaming chairs.

The Project Arielle fan attaches to the Fujin and Fujin Pro backrests and, according to Razer's press release, can reduce the perceived temperature by between 2 to 5 degrees Celsius (roughly 3.5 to 5.5 degrees Fahrenheit) with fan noise "as soft as a whisper." It also features energy-efficient heaters that can deliver warm air up to 30 degrees Celsius (86 degrees Fahrenheit), making it helpful in any environment. Temperature and fan speeds are controlled via a touch panel on the side of the seat, and it can be easily attached or removed from the chair thanks to a quick-release connection.

Pricing and release date information has not been revealed, though Razer is demoing Project Arielle in person at its CES 2025 booth, so we expect the fan add-on to launch in the near future. In the meantime, the Razer Fujin Pro is available now, starting at $1,050 at Razer's online store. The standard Razer Fujin gaming chair is available for a 25% discount at Amazon, which drops the price from $650 to $500. Both models feature similar mesh materials and chair dimensions, but the standard Fujin lacks a few of the features of the Fujin Pro, including a headrest. Luckily, there's an optional headrest add-on for the Fujin available for $130 at Best Buy.

Razer Fujin Mesh Gaming Chairs

  • Razer Fujin Pro Mesh Gaming Chair -- $1,050
  • Razer Fujin Mesh Gaming Chair -- $500 ($650) at Amazon | $650 at Razer
  • Razer Fujin Mesh Headrest Add-On -- $130

Razer Iskur V2 X Gaming Chair

The second of Razer's new gaming chair announcements is the new Razer Iskur V2 X model. This new iteration of Razer's budget chair retains the same ergonomics and lumbar support of the original Iskur V2, including the same deep, 152-degree recline, but with a widened seat base of up to 545mm. The Razer Iskur V2 X also features 2D adjustable armrests, high-density foam cushioning, and multi-layered upholstery in multiple color options. It's available now starting at $300 at Amazon and Razer's online store.

Razer Enki Gaming Chair Deals

It's worth noting that Amazon has deals on Razer's mid-range Enki gaming chairs right now. The standard Razer Enki is on sale for $450 in black and black/green, while the pink edition is available for $440. Meanwhile, the entry-level Enki X is on sale for $339 in black/green and $350 in black.

  • Razer Enki X Gaming Chair (Black/Green) -- $339 ($400)
  • Razer Enki X Gaming Chair (Black) -- $350 ($400)
  • Razer Enki Gaming Chair (Black) -- $450 ($500)
  • Razer Enki Gaming Chair (Black/Green) -- $450 ($500)
  • Razer Enki Gaming Chair (Quartz) -- $440 ($500)

More Razer CES 2025 Reveals

These new gaming chair announcements are just a few of the new products Razer unveiled at CES 2025. The company also previewed its thinnest gaming laptop yet, the new Razer Blade 16 2025 model. It also showed off a new mobile gaming dock compatible with smartphones and handheld gaming devices like the Steam Deck, and announced a free update for its Razer Nexus mobile app that will let you stream gameplay directly from your PC to a smartphone or Razer Edge gaming tablet.

item.title: GeForce RTX 50-Series GPUs - Nvidia's New Graphics Cards, Explained
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/nvidia-geforce-rtx-50-series-gpu-preorder-where-to-buy/1100-6528684/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Nvidia revealed its next generation of graphics cards, the GeForce RTX 50-series, at CES this week. There are four new GPUs in the lineup: the Geforce RTX 5090, 5080, 5070, and 5070 Ti.

The flagship card, the RTX 5090, is priced at $2,000, and Nvidia claims it's twice as powerful as the RTX 4090 but requires a 1,000-watt power supply--a huge leap from the RTX 4090's 450W baseline power draw. Despite its power demands, the RTX 5090 is more compact than its predecessor, fitting into smaller PC builds.

The slimmer size and higher performance are true of all the cards in the lineup, with Nvidia claiming the $1,000 RTX 5080 to be twice as fast as the RTX 4080. The budget-priced $550 RTX 5070 offers performance comparable to the RTX 4090, at nearly a third of the price. The 5070 Ti, meanwhile, sits between the 5070 and 5080 in terms of price ($750) and performance.

Rather than relying on pure processing power to achieve these benchmarks, the new 50-series cards leverage Nvidia's latest machine learning technology, including RTX Neural Shaders and the latest DLSS 4 upscaling. Not only does DLSS 4 allow for upscaling lower-resolution gameplay to 1440p or 4K resolutions, it also includes Multi Frame Generation, which Nvidia says is capable of generating up to three additional frames for every one frame of rendered gameplay. It's essentially doing for gaming what frame smoothing does for movies and TVs and creating the appearance of higher, smoother frame rates without the hardware actually rendering them all.

So, while the 50-series GPUs' actual hardware performance uplift is technically lower in terms of raw processing power without the aid of AI technology--the 5070 has less processing power than the 4090, for instance--it also means the GPUs are smaller and more affordable compared to their previous-gen counterparts since you don't need as much horsepower to achieve high-end results.

Of course, AI upscaling and frame generation have tradeoffs compared to rendering everything with hardware. These machine learning technologies can potentially match hardware rendering the quantity of performance, but the issue is the quality of that performance. Upscalers like DLSS, AMD's FSR, and Sony's PSSR on PS5 Pro can be inconsistent (or even incorrect, in extreme cases), while frame generation can introduce noticeable input delay--something that playing at high frame rates is intended to alleviate, not exacerbate.

To be fair, these are issues Nvidia--and game developers--are aware of and actively working to address. Besides, plenty of games already utilize the features to great results, and the 40-series cards used DLSS to achieve big performance gains over the 30-series--unfortunately, it was also incredibly expensive. If the next generation of the technology works as intended, the 5090 could enable another massive performance boost, while the mid-range RTX 50 GPUs could offer a much more affordable option for achieving 4K resolution gameplay and high FPS.

Where to preorder the GeForce RTX 5090, 5080, 5070 Ti, and 5070

If you're sold on Nvidia's promise of AI-powered graphics processing, you'll be glad to know the new GPUs are launching soon. The RTX 5090 and RTX 5080 launch on January 30, while the 5070 and 5070 Ti will arrive in February. While preorders are not yet live, listings for the GeForce RTX 5090 and RTX 5080 GPUs are up at Best Buy, and you can sign up to be notified once they're available for purchase. We'll update this post once preorders are available.

Note that these listings are for Nvidia's reference card models; third-party 50-series GPUs will likely roll out soon after Nvidia's models launch. Nvidia also confirmed RTX 50-series laptop GPUs are on the way, with the first models expected to launch in March.

Nvidia GeForce RTX 50-series GPU preorders

  • GeForce RTX 5090 -- $2,000 | Launches January 30
  • GeForce RTX 5080 -- $1,000 | Launches January 30
  • GeForce RTX 5070 Ti -- $750 | Launches February
  • GeForce RTX 5070 -- $550 | Launches February

item.title: The New Carmen Sandiego Game Getting A Physical 40th Anniversary Edition On Nintendo Switch And PS5
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-new-carmen-sandiego-game-getting-a-physical-40th-anniversary-edition-on-nintendo-switch-and-ps5/1100-6528676/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Carmen Sandiego has been traveling the world since 1985, evading capture as she steals some of the most valuable artifacts on the planet, and soon she'll be setting off on a new heist with the new puzzle-adventure game Carmen Sandiego on PS5, Xbox Series X, Switch, PC, and Netflix (as a mobile game). While previous titles task you with tracking down the glob-trotting thief, this is the first game in the series' history in which you’ll get to play Carmen Sandiego. Preorders are now open for Carmen Sandiego ahead of its April 17 release, and there’s even a deluxe 40th Anniversary Edition packed with collectible goodies.

Carmen Sandiego Preorder Bonus

No preorder bonuses have been announced for Carmen Sandiego. We’ll update this section if anything is revealed ahead of launch, including retailer-exclusive bonuses.

Carmen Sandiego 40th Anniversary Edition

$50

The Carmen Sandiego 40th Anniversary Edition is the only physical version of the game available. Grabbing this edition gets you the base game plus a bunch of physical and digital collectibles, including:

  • Anniversary Caper "Where in the World"
  • Cosmetic Skin - Classic outfit
  • Cosmetic Skin - Motorcycle outfit
  • Digital Official Soundtrack
  • Digital Official Art Book
  • Collectible Map
  • Collectible Stickers

Carmen Sandiego: 40th Anniversary Edition is available for $50 on Nintendo Switch and PS5, though the PS5 version is currently sold out. That said, it's likely to be restocked before release, so keep checking Amazon's store page.

Carmen Sandiego Standard Edition (Digital)

$30

The standard edition of Carmen Sandiego is only available in digital formats. It includes the base game and nothing more, though it’s priced reasonably at just $30. You’ll find it on the Xbox Store, PlayStation Store, Switch eShop, and Steam.

Carmen Sandiego Digital Deluxe Edition

$50

There is also a Carmen Sandiaego Digital Deluxe edition that includes the base game and digital bonuses from the physical 40th anniversary edition--though you'll miss out on the physical goodies. Still, if you're looking to upgrade your digital version, this is a great option. Here's all the Carmen Sandiego Digital Deluxe Edition bonuses:

  • Anniversary Caper "Where in the World"
  • Cosmetic Skin - Classic outfit
  • Cosmetic Skin - Motorcycle outfit
  • Digital Official Soundtrack
  • Digital Official Art Book

Note that some platforms sell this as a bundle with the base game for $50, while others offer it as DLC for the base game at $25. It’s available on Steam, the Switch eShop, the PlayStation Store, and Xbox Store. If you're looking for the best deal, the the best platform to purchase the deluxe edition, as it’s currently listed for $40.

item.title: Assassin's Creed Shadows Is Adding Some New Parkour Moves And Bringing Back Familiar Options
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/assassins-creed-shadows-is-adding-some-new-parkour-moves-and-bringing-back-familiar-options/1100-6528682/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Parkour has been an important part of the Assassin's Creed franchise from the beginning, but Assassin's Creed Shadows will be making some adjustments to the acrobatic running style. Ubisoft has already hinted that Naoe--one of Shadows' new leading characters--can Naruto run in the game. But that's just the beginning of what she can pull off while running.

Ubisoft has shared an extensive breakdown of Shadow's new parkour options, as well as the revised button map for the game. One of the most notable changes is that the crouch and the dodge buttons have traded places. That will allow the player to either crouch or lie in a prone position. Naoe can even kill her targets while lying prone.

Yasuke--the game's other lead character--and Naoe can both perform dodges while crouched, but only the latter can pull off a dodge in her prone stance. The other new parkour moves that Naoe can pull off include a wall-run eject and a backward dodge, which you can see below.

Some of the parkour and climbing moves can be performed by both Yasuke and Naoe, but she's more suited for those because she's light on her feet and able to pull off a recovery roll while falling.

The developers also noted that not every wall surface in the game will be climbable for either character. The grappling hook can help players overcome some of those areas, but they will also have to be on the lookout for surfaces that have physical handholds to grab.

For players who don't want to deal with romances or branching narrative paths, Shadows will have a Canon Mode, which will make the big story decisions for you. Shadows will also introduce a new direction for the modern-day storyline. A few of the details about the game's battle pass have leaked online, and Ubisoft has stated that the rewards in the Animus Hub will be free.

Assassin's Creed Shadows will hit PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC on February 14, 2025.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Nvidia's DLSS 4 Promises Big Performance Gains For Both New And Old Hardware
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/nvidias-dlss-4-promises-big-performance-gains-for-both-new-and-old-hardware/1100-6528680/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Nvidia finally revealed their next-generation RTX 50-series graphics cards at CES 2025, with some big performance improvements expected thanks to the new Blackwell architecture. But since 2020 and the launch of the RTX 20 series, Nvidia has been working on and expanding its range of AI enhancements as part of its DLSS suite of exclusive features, with its latest iteration, DLSS 4, set to propel both new and older GPUs forward.

DLSS 4's biggest new feature is one that will be exclusive to the new RTX 50-series GPUs. Multi Frame Generation is the next step in the Frame Generation race that Nvidia kicked off with the RTX 40-series range. Instead of just injecting a single, AI-generated frame between two traditionally rendered one, Multi Frame Generation now offers up to four AI-generated frames to be inserted, substantially increasing a game's frame rate. Nvidia says that its new GPUs can deliver nearly eight times more performance than "brute-force" rendering, but how well each generated frame looks and how this impacts input latency has yet to be determined.

Digital Foundry was given access to an engineering sample of the RTX 5080 and limited time to test Multi Frame Generation in Cyberpunk 2077 and came away impressed with both the image quality and fluidity of the experience.

Perhaps more interesting are the DLSS 4 improvements that will be supported on all of Nvidia's RTX GPUs. Nvidia has updated its transformer model that powers DLSS Super Sampling, Ray Reconstruction, and DLAA for the first time, moving away from its previous convolutional neural networks approach. What this means is that its newer model is more adept at identifying parts of a rendered image that are important and with more granularity, offering up more stable upscaling and ray-tracing quality as a result.

DLSS Super Resolution (Nvidia's AI-enhanced upscaling solution), Ray Reconstruction, and DLAA will be improving thanks to this upgrade across all RTX hardware, starting with the RTX 20 series. Nvidia is also adding the ability to switch between specific DLSS releases from within its GeForce Experience application in the near future, which previously had to be manually done for each game if you wanted to experiment with newer DLSS versions that hadn't been patched in by developers. This can potentially give some new life to older hardware, at least from an image-quality standpoint.

There's no question that the headline feature for DLSS 4 is the one that only works on Nvidia's latest and greatest hardware, which starts shipping later this month and will be supported in over 75 games and apps immediately. But unlike the update for Frame Generation with the RTX 40 series launch, there's a lot more to get excited about for the many more already on Nvidia's platform.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
